ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

IMPROVED FLOORINGS FOR NEW HDB FLATS


    1. Mr Sia Kah Hui asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board will consider completing new flats with tile, marble or parquet floorings so that buyers can move in immediately on receiving the keys.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB will continue its existing practice of providing floor finishes for the kitchens and bathrooms of newly-completed flats, but will not extend standard floor finishes to other rooms. Any standard floor finish provided is unlikely to satisfy the wide range of tastes of flat buyers. Most of them want to select finishes according to their individual preferences and budgets. The HDB's existing practice allows them this flexibility.

    The provision of standard floorings for kitchens and bathrooms is necessary to reduce damage to these wet areas, and hence minimise the possibility of water leakage. Even then, the HDB's experience shows that many owners hack up the standard kitchen flooring and retile them after the minimum 3-year period during which retiling is prohibited. Flat owners have to bear the cost of repairing any damages to the kitchen and toilet floors as a result of hacking. The HDB feels that owners are likely to replace standard floor finishes in other rooms if these are provided. This practice is a waste of both materials and labour. The provision of floor finishes in itself will not enable flat buyers to move in immediately, as there will be other renovation works required, like repainting of walls, installation of window grilles, etc.

    In contrast to conventionally built flats, HDB's prefab flats are completed with tiled flooring. This is because the industrialized method of construction requires floor finishes to be cast at the same time as the prefab floors. Owners of prefab flats are not allowed to hack up the floor for

Column: 2068

retiling, as this may cause damage to the joints resulting in possible water seepage.

    Flat buyers therefore have the choice of selecting prefab flats with floor finishes that are suitable for them or opting for conventionally built flats and carrying out their own floor finishes.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. Is the Minister not aware that times have changed and continue to change? There are already so many complaints from flat buyers against the sub-contractors. I have here just two samples, one from the Singapore Monitor and the other from the Straits Times. One heading reads, "Angry flat owners want their money back", and the other heading, "Contractor vanishes before jobs are completed". So I say that the times have changed and that the flats in Tampines are welcomed by the buyers because the floors are all done up nicely. The number of people -

     Mr Speaker: What is your supplementary question, Mr Sia?

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: I wonder whether the Minister is aware that times have changed and that the people buying the flats in Tampines -

     Mr Speaker: Well, let him first answer about times having changed.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, I am aware.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui: So is the Minister not going to consider that since times have changed therefore the policy has got to be changed too? Follow up with the times.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member did not pay much attention to what I said just now. I said that flat buyers have the. choice of selecting prefab flats with floor finishes, ie those who want finishes that are suitable for them, or opting for conventionally built flats and carry out their own flooring finishes. In other words, the buyer has a choice. For those who want flats with finishes, HDB has built flats with finishes. For those who do not want them, they can opt for the conventional type of construction. So they have a choice.

RESIGNATION OF BRIG-GEN LEE HSIEN LOONG


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health whether the impending resignation of Brigadier Lee Hsien Loong from the Army was known or expected when he was promoted to that rank.

     The Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, promotions in the Singapore Armed Forces are decided through a strictly defined set of procedures. The present procedures were published in the March 1982 issue of the Pointer, a publication for SAF officers. The factors considered in a promotion are performance on the job, potential for higher level appointments, character, and recommendations of superiors.

    The SAF has a system of regular annual promotion exercises. The process begins around February and ends in June. Promotions are effective from 1st July of the year in question.

    In the 1984 promotion exercise, the SAF Promotions Council recommended a number of promotions including Col Lee Hsien Loong. That recommendation together with others were accepted by the Minister. It was made irrespective of any contemplated resignation because the decision to promote is made purely on the basis of the officer's capacity to contribute to the SAF. Furthermore, unlike the situation in the civilian sector, SAF regulars who leave active service are still members of the SAF. As reservist officers or NCOs, they can expect to play as important a role or, if they upgrade themselves, even a greater role than when they were in active service.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. If the resignation of the officer was known at the time the promotion was considered, may I ask the Minister what was the urgency in promoting him, if he was going to resign from active service in the Army? Is it not possible for him to have gone on the reservist strength and then be promoted through that, if he was found suitable for promotion?

Column: 2070



     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have explained, the promotion of officers in the SAF depends on a number of factors: his experience, character, contribution to the SAF. In the case of Col Lee Hsien Loong, he was found worthy of promotion this year by the Promotions Council, and he was accordingly recommended for promotion. I have no reason to disagree with the recommendation of the Promotions Council. There was no need whatsoever to defer the promotion of a good officer who richly deserved to be promoted this year.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister be good enough to say how long this officer had been in active service in the Army before he was promoted to the rank of Brigadier? And would the Minister be good enough to say whether this has its parallel in any other army in the world except perhaps in armies which have taken over from their colonial masters?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, had the Member for Anson listened carefully to my reply, he would have learned that promotion in the SAF depends on merit amongst other things. As to how long the officer has served in a particular position, it is not relevant. The officer can be serving in a position for any number of years, but if he lacks the potential to manage bigger responsibilities, he will not be promoted. I suggest the Member for Anson secure a copy of the March 1982 Pointer where he will get all the answers to the open system which we run in the promotion of officers in the SAF.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister if he will be good enough to answer my questions. My question, I repeat, is how long has this officer been in active service in the Army before he was promoted, and whether this has a parallel in any other army? And if I may add another question to it, would the Minister say whether the officer was promoted so that he could be advanced in his political career, so that he could be appointed Political Secretary to the Minister of Defence? Was that the real reason for his promotion?

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, as the former Defence Minister, may I be permitted to make some observations. I consider this supplementary question from the Member for Anson to be totally unworthy of a Member of this Parliament. He, by aided innuendo, suggested that the promotion of Brig-Gen Lee was motivated by unworthy considerations, such as a move to accelerate his career in the political field or by virtue of his relationship with the Prime Minister. I challenge the Member to make this innuendo outside the privileged walls of this House and we will see whether or not he will get away with a libel suit.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was going to make the same line of answer to the Member for Anson, and I am pleased that the First Deputy Prime Minister has stood up to do what I would have done.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, am I, in this House, not entitled to this information? What is so secret about this that the information cannot be given in this House? It is not a question of making any innuendoes.

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: All the facts he wanted have been given by the Minister. What he wanted to do is, by innuendo, to suggest that there is some secret skullduggery going on. I suggest that he makes his accusation in the open.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I still have the Floor. I am not here to make innuendoes. I am asking questions and I say the House is entitled to this information; not the House alone but the people at large in Singapore. The information has not been given. The information is, how long has this officer been in active service in the Army? Secondly, has this got a parallel in any other army? Thirdly, I want a categorical answer whether he was promoted to advance his political career?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: The career of Brig-Gen Lee is well-known to the public. It has been published in the newspapers. Why then does he come out with all this drivel, other than to impute improper motives?

Column: 2072



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, I object to the term "drivel" as spelt out by the First Deputy Prime Minister. He should know better as a Member of this House. May I ask the Minister whether he would agree to a Committee of this House inquiring into this promotion?

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, if that is not drivel, I ask you, Sir, as an independent observer, whether that is not the most nonsensical question ever to come up from a nonsensical MP?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, you, as the Speaker may disallow any question if you thought it was improper, and I have not heard you disallowing the question. I am asking the question whether the Minister will allow a Committee of this House to look into this promotion, to see how many other officers were passed over.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no need to set up a Committee to investigate what the First Deputy Prime Minister called "drivel". I would repeat what the First Deputy Prime Minister has said. If the Member for Anson seriously believes that there has been any wrong-doing in the promotion of any officer in the SAF, he should have the courage to state this outside the House and not suggest this within the House so that he could be protected from any libel suit against him.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Do the Minister and the First Deputy Prime Minister not realize that it is not a question of them assuring that everything was done perfectly, properly? It is a question of the public being told, so that it is seen to be done properly. That is one of the first principles of public administration and of justice.

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, since that was not a supplementary question, may I be allowed to comment briefly on that. When we form a Committee of the House to inquire into an activity of the Government, the assumption must be that there has been something improper. In this instance, where is the impropriety? The Member for Anson has been trying, through devious means of questioning, by innuendo, to suggest that there is something improper.

Well, let us have it from him and hear him say so outside this House where he will have no defence of privilege. When I said that that was a drivel, he just stood up to confirm that what I said beats his record for nonsensical outpourings.

WOODLANDS HOME FOR THE AGED
(Outbreak of cholera)


    3. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Social Affairs if he will make a statement on the recent outbreak of cholera in the Woodlands Home for the Aged.

    4. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for Social Affairs (a) what were the causes for the outbreak of cholera and subsequent deaths in the Woodlands Home for the Aged; (b) whether he is satisfied with the hygienic conditions of all the "Homes" in Singapore; and (c) what measures are being taken to prevent recurrence of similar situations.

     The Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, since Questions 3 and 4 are related, may I be permitted to answer them together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Thank you, Sir. Mr Speaker, Sir, the recent outbreak of

Column: 2074

cholera in the Woodlands Home for the Aged was caused by the introduction of cholera bacteria into the Home from an outside source. A resident helper in the kitchen was infected through consuming contaminated food brought to him by a relative. He developed diarrhoea on 14 August and was diagnosed to be suffering from cholera on 18 August. Up to 7 September, a total of 21 residents were infected with cholera and 76 were identified as carriers.

    Four of the cholera victims died. The causes of death were 'acute myocardial infarction' and 'acute cerebral infarction' in an 85-year old resident, 'cardio-respiratory failure' in an 82-year old resident, 'acute intestinal gangrene' in a 75-year old resident and 'acute gastroenteritis' in a 90-year old resident. It can be seen that two of the four victims died because of their frailty and low resistance to the cholera bacteria.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, certain newspapers have given wide publicity to the outbreak and attributed the spreading of the disease within the Home mainly to the unsanitary condition of the toilets. While a few toilets serving the male residents were defective at the time of the outbreak and some others were not quite clean, these were in themselves not the main cause for the spread of the disease in the Home. The frailty of most of the residents in the Home, many of whom are incontinent and have poor control over their bowels, were a more significant factor. It was unfortunate that an infected resident helper in the kitchen was not detected as a cholera victim and isolated until after several days. He was the initial source of the spread of the cholera.

    My staff have done what they could within the available manpower resources of the Woodlands Home for the Aged. Mr Speaker, Sir, the relevant issue to consider here is whether we can afford to deploy a staff force to ensure at all times personal hygiene and complete cleanliness of the toilets and premises of these Homes. Although the State has a duty to care for the residents in these Welfare Homes, I am of the view that we must do the best with the resources available.

Column: 2075



Measures taken to prevent recurrence of similar situations

    The Member for Chong Boon has asked what measures have been taken to prevent recurrence of similar situations. Mr Speaker, Sir, this incident in the Woodlands Home was an unfortunate one. The Home has been in existence for 20 years and there has hitherto been no epidemic or even food poisoning.

    Nonetheless, we have taken several immediate measures to prevent recurrence of a similar outbreak. Only freshly cooked food is allowed into the Homes. All residents and food handlers are made to wash their hands before touching food and drinks. All food handlers will be screened regularly by the Ministry of Health. A new working procedure for minor repairs has been introduced which allows the Superintendent of the Home to get the work done by any nearby contractor if the term contractor appointed by PWD fails to respond to a request for minor repairs within a reasonable time. The existing PVC toilet cisterns will be phased out and replaced by heavy duty ones.

Hygienic Conditions of the Homes

    The Ministry of Social Affairs runs three Homes for the aged and destitutes and nine Homes for children and young persons. I am satisfied with the hygienic conditions of these Homes. Frequent inspections we conducted by my staff and by members of the Boards of Visitors appointed by the Director of Social Welfare.

    For the long term, my Ministry has instituted a thorough review of all its institutions. The review may result in the relocation of some Homes to more appropriate localities with purpose-built facilities.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister why the toilets were in an unsatisfactory condition in the first place.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the problem of dirty and choked toilets is not. peculiar to Woodlands Home for the Aged only. It happens almost everywhere.

Column: 2076

Maybe I should draw the attention of the Member to an article which appeared in one of the September issues of Sunday Times. I cannot remember the date. In fact, this article was written by an employee of the Straits Times. She bemoans the fact that we Singaporeans have not been educated in our toilet habits. According to her, even young, healthy office workers dirty the toilets no matter how new the environment of the office and the toilets may be.

    Even in the Straits Times, according to her, although the toilets are about two years old, the handles to the water closets are already breaking and repairs to choked toilets have been less than prompt. Only a couple of days ago we read in The Monitor that the sanitation in the toilets of NUS has improved after the Member for Whampoa brought it up at an exhibition last week.

    Sir, the problem with the Woodlands Home for the Aged is that, as I mentioned in my answer earlier on, most of the 600-plus residents are old, incontinent and have poor control over their bowels. But we will do our best with whatever resources available.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister answer the question that was asked of him by the last Member, and that is, how long have the lavatories been not functioning properly in this Woodlands Home for the Aged before the cholera outbreak was detected?

    Secondly, has the Home adequate staff to cope adequately with bedridden patients, people who are unable to take care of themselves in their bowel movements or their habits, or are they just left to look after themselves?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: To answer the first question, repairs were done almost immediately after it happened.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: How long were they malfunctioning?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: As I replied to the Member for Chong Boon, because of the fact that the residents are old, frail and incontinent, dirty and choked toilets occur frequently and we attend to them as soon as we can.

Column: 2077



    To his second question, with the present staff to resident ratio of 1:12, 1 think we can manage with the problem. We have been managing this for the last 20 years. We will continue to manage. We will do our best with the resources available.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister appoint a committee to inquire into the conditions at the Woodlands Home for the Aged before the outbreak of cholera and the causes that led to this outbreak?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: The answer is no. I have my Boards of Visitors appointed by the Director of Social Welfare and they consist of members of the public. They visit the Homes regularly, not only the Woodlands Home for the Aged but all the other Homes under the Ministry. There is no need for any committee of inquiry.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say whether he has made any inquiry, whether through his Boards of Visitors or through his officials, and if he has, will he make public the report of this committee or Board that inquired into it?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: I have inquired into the events that led to the cholera outbreak, and the answer today is a report of that report.

INDOOR NATIONAL STADIUM


    5. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for Social Affairs whether there are any definite plans to build a modern "Indoor National Stadium" in Singapore in the very near future and, if so, what are the details of the proposed Indoor Stadium.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am pleased to inform the Member for Chong Boon that my Ministry supports the proposal by the Singapore Sports Council to build a modern international indoor stadium at Kallang Park, near to the National Stadium. Estimated to cost $45 million, the Indoor Stadium now proposed will have a capacity of 15,000 to cater to sports activities, conventions, family entertainment shows, exhibitions, cultural and other events.

    The arena will accommodate two basketball and eight badminton courts which can

Column: 2078

also be used for all other indoor sports. The Stadium will conform to specifications of international standards which include unobstructed views from the galleries and air-conditioning. There will be special lighting for different sports and at different illumination levels, public address system with controls to different areas, matrix scoreboards, adequate changing rooms, showers and toilets for players and spectators. We will also have supporting facilities for staff and members of the media.

    A feasibility study conducted by the Singapore Sports Council indicates that the proposed international Indoor Stadium should be well utilized.
